results.title: ‘Fast Furniture’ Is Cheap. And Americans Are Throwing It in the Trash.
results.abstract: The mass-produced furniture that sold furiously during the pandemic could soon be clogging landfills.

media.caption: Consumers spent $4 billion from 2019 to 2021 on furniture in the United States. Environmentalists say that a lot of the products sold during the pandemic weren’t built to last.

results.title: Thomas Cahill, Popular Writer of Ireland’s History, Dies at 82
results.abstract: His book “How the Irish Saved Civilization” became a best seller and helped open the door to a new appreciation of that country’s culture.

media.caption: Thomas Cahill, the author of “How the Irish Saved Civilization,” in 2005. He had a firm mastery of both primary sources and the academic scholarship around them, and he was also a fluid, engaging writer.

results.title: Miami Collectors Shake Up a D.C. Schoolhouse
results.abstract: The Rubells open a new contemporary art museum, extending their reach to the capital with some 200 works and a nod to Marvin Gaye.

media.caption: The Rubell family — Jason, Mera and Donald — with Vaughn Spann’s “Big Black Rainbow (Smoky Eyes)” in the new Rubell Museum DC. The inaugural show, “What’s Going On,” is named for Marvin Gaye, who attended school in the original building.

results.title: A Godfather of Chinese Nationalism Has Second Thoughts
results.abstract: Wang Xiaodong, once called the standard-bearer of Chinese nationalism, now fends off criticisms of being too moderate, even a traitor. “They’ve forgotten,” he said, “I created them.”

results.adx_keywords: Art;Beirut, Lebanon, Explosions (2020);Restoration and Renovation;Gentileschi, Artemisia;Getty, J Paul, Museum;Lebanon
results.title: Damaged by an Explosion, the Canvas Emerged a Gentileschi
results.abstract: A painting that was scarred by the 2020 blast in Beirut is now attributed to Artemisia Gentileschi, the great 17th-century Italian painter known for her depiction of strong women.

media.caption: “Hercules and Omphale,” by Artemisia Gentileschi, is being repaired at the Getty Museum’s conservation studio in Los Angeles. It had hung in the Sursock Palace in Beirut as an anonymous 17th-century painting.
media.copyright: Brian Guido for The New York Times
